PostValue.explanation: This is a useful, concrete operational update about a national EA group's activities, funding, and programs — important for EA Philippines members, local organizers, and potential funders/donors but not foundational to core EA or global policy questions. If accurate it matters for regional community growth, allocation of small-to-midsize funds, and confidence in local capacity; if false the harms are mostly reputational/misallocation at a local scale. It has low direct bearing on high‑stakes EA priorities (longtermism, global AI risk) and limited relevance to broader humanity beyond Philippines‑level impacts.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: I have no record (up to my 2024-06 cutoff) of a notable EA/rationalist presence or public profile for 'Samantha Ackary' — no major publications, talks, or visibility on EA, LessWrong, 80,000 Hours, or mainstream sources. Likely unknown or a pseudonym; recommend a web/LinkedIn search for current info.

PostClarity.explanation: Well-structured, easy to follow and appropriately concise: clear headings, tables, and bullet points make the content quickly digestible and the main points (leadership changes, funding, programs, milestones) are communicated effectively. Minor issues reduce perfection: a few small inconsistencies (future-dated program inside a past-period report), slight formatting/wording quirks (e.g., pluralization like "Komunidads", extra punctuation), and limited impact metrics/context for some programs. Fixing those would push it toward a 9–10.

PostNovelty.explanation: This is primarily an organizational progress report with routine items (leadership changes, funding breakdown, programs, events, community health work). For EA Forum readers, the content is familiar — local chapter updates, fellowships, fundraising diversification and community-building practices are common — so only mildly novel (specific local details like the planned EA Philippines Summit or local projects in AI safety/animal welfare are somewhat new but not conceptually original). For the general public, the report is standard non‑profit operational information and not novel.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: The post is clear and logically organized, with transparent financial tables, specific program descriptions, and concrete short-term engagement metrics (attendance, recommendation scores, capstone projects). The budget and expense breakdowns are specific and verifiable, and leadership/organizational changes are documented. Weaknesses: Causal links between activities and longer-term impact are asserted but not evidenced; program evaluation details (sample sizes, survey methodology, follow-up outcomes) are missing; the claim of diversified funding is overstated given ~82% reliance on one source; and there is little external validation or outcome data for the highlighted local organizations. Overall, the report provides moderate support for progress on activities and outputs but limited evidence for sustained impact.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes:
Most major claims in the briefer are supported by primary sources from EA Philippines and corroborating community/grant pages. EA Philippines’ website and multiple EA Forum posts confirm the leadership change (Sam Ackary & Zian Bonoan as Co‑Directors), the board members named, the running of introductory fellowships and community activities, and plans for a Philippines summit. The largest funding claim (≈USD 43k from the Meta Charity Funders round) is explicitly confirmed by the Meta Charity Funders retrospective. Healthy Futures Global’s Philippines work and Department of Health partnership is corroborated by a GiveWell summary. Animal Empathy Philippines and Phlourish have active websites corroborating their existence and leadership. 

Limitations: many of the numerical details (the exact breakdowns of CEA funding listed as ~USD 7,054; the precise expense table and remaining cash balance; attendance counts like “69 Filipino EAs at EAGxSingapore 2024” and some volunteer counts) come from EA Philippines’ internal reporting (the forum post / briefer) and are not independently verifiable from public third‑party sources; CEA’s Group Support funding mechanism is public but CEA does not publish a public ledger of individual small grant amounts to confirm the exact USD 7,054 figure. Given this, I judge the briefer as mostly accurate and well‑supported on high‑level claims (leadership, receipt of major grant, existence of partner orgs and programs), but some specific numeric claims rely on EA Philippines’ internal accounting and are only partially externally verifiable.
sources: EA Forum — "🇵🇭 EA Philippines Progress Report Briefer (April 2024 - March 2025)" (forum post) — evidence for program claims, finance tables and attendance numbers. (EA Forum post by Samantha Ackary). — https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/LoH8iix8AJKGS4zvM/ea-philippines-progress-report-briefer-april-2024-march-2025
EA Philippines — About Us (official site) — confirms Co‑Directors, board membership and local group listings. — https://www.effectivealtruism.ph/about-us

Meta Charity Funders — "Second round retrospective" (EA Forum summary) — shows EA Philippines funded ~$43k in that Meta Charity Funders round. — https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/RfwmZa4qb7F3BaLG2/meta-charity-funders-second-round-retrospective

Centre for Effective Altruism (CEA) — Group Support Funding page — describes CEA group funding mechanisms referenced in the briefer (verifies that CEA provides such grants even if it does not list the specific EA PH grant amount publicly). — https://www.centreforeffectivealtruism.org/group-support-funding

GiveWell — "Healthy Futures Global — Syphilis Screening and Treatment in the Philippines (Feb 2025)" — documents Healthy Futures Global’s Philippines program and DoH partnership plans referenced in the briefer. — https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/healthy-futures-global-syphilis-screening-and-treatment-in-the-philippines-february-2025

Animal Empathy Philippines — official site (animalempathy.ph) — confirms Animal Empathy Philippines’ existence and leadership (Kate Lupango referenced in the briefer). — https://animalempathy.ph/our-story/ and https://animalempathy.ph/our-team

EA Forum — "How we held a successful 1st Introductory EA Fellowship in the University of the Philippines" — corroborates that EA groups in the Philippines ran introductory fellowships with high participation and high recommendation scores (context for the briefer's fellowship claims). — https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/hjykgdqo2zDByqg6E/how-we-held-a-successful-1st-introductory-ea-fellowship-in
EA Global / EAGxSingapore 2024 event page — confirms the EAGxSingapore 2024 event (context for the attendance claim). — https://www.effectivealtruism.org/ea-global/events/eagxsingapore-2024

EA Global — EA Summit: Philippines (2025) event listing — corroborates that an EA Philippines summit for Sept 2025 is listed on EA Global's events pages. — https://www.effectivealtruism.org/ea-global/events/ea-summit-philippines

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Funding concentration, runway, and transparency: The report says you “diversified” funding but ~82% of revenue came from one source (Meta). That’s a major sustainability risk and an important reader concern. Actionable fixes: explicitly state your cash runway, reserve policy, and the budget target you say you exceeded; explain plans/targets to reduce single-funder concentration (timelines, specific grant prospects, contingency if Meta funding ends), and clarify intended use of the ~PHP1.43M on-hand (restricted vs unrestricted and planned spend over the next 12 months).

2) Lack of outcome/impact metrics beyond attendance and satisfaction: The post reports outputs (attendees, fellows, recommendation scores) but no follow-up or outcome measures that speak to impact (e.g., retention of fellows in EA-aligned projects, concrete projects started, policy/advocacy wins, measurable behavior changes). Actionable fixes: add 2–4 clear, realistic outcome indicators you will track (with baseline/targets and data collection plans), or, if not available, acknowledge this limitation and commit to a timeline for collecting outcomes (e.g., 6–12 month follow-up survey, alumni tracking).

3) Clarity on reporting window, future programs, and governance: There are several confusing timelines (reporting period is Apr 2024–Mar 2025, but some programs are dated May–June 2025) and limited governance detail. Actionable fixes: explicitly state the reporting period at the top, move or label future programs as "Upcoming (post-reporting period)", and add a brief governance section: board roles, selection process, conflict-of-interest policy, and whether board members are independent or affiliated with funders/staff. This will reduce perceived opacity and strengthen donor/trust signals.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback hits the report's most important weaknesses: misleading claim of ‘diversified’ funding when ~82% is from one source (an own-goal that would embarrass the authors if pointed out), missing cash-runway / reserve policy details, lack of outcome/impact metrics beyond attendance, and confusing timelines/governance opacity. Each point is actionable and would materially improve donor/trust signals without requiring a long rewrite. It loses a couple of points because the suggestions are already fairly standard and don’t call out a few smaller clarity issues (e.g., currency/ FTE formatting inconsistencies) that could be fixed with minimal edits, but overall this is high-value, practical feedback.
